description.text:
This is designed particularly for city-dwelling ladies (or adventurous men). It slips over the tip of the heel to protect it en route to your final destination. You can apparently buy these for $10 from a number of places. Take that Big High-Heel Protector! 
They're designed for heels with a roughly .45" square tip (the test pair they were designed for - I don't really know what other sizes are out there).
Now updated to be slightly rounded on the rear/side edges, to decrease scuffing.
Just print out two copies, slip them on and start walkin'.

comments.text: I'm about to do similar protectors for my wifes dancing shoes. What experiences are out in terms of durability? It's statically about 35kg per protector, beeing squeezed between the small surface of the heel and the floor. Does the material not break? Industrially made heel protectors are mainly made from very elastic material but with bad durability.

Soldering clip is a tool designed to facilitate the welding of wires supporting them in its tubings.
Fans, practitioners, students and makers often use solder the wires with the pond and a support that is comfortable underpinning the wires.
This is a cheap and very simple solution that will help them in the work. -My passion for 3D printing was born at Rome Maker Faire. I made lots of drawings and I studied well the characteristics of 3d printing in all its stages. I have many projects ready to be printed, but I can't afford to buy or build a printer. I hopethat by partecipating in this competition, I can finally give life to my project. It's my childhood dream. Thanks! -

It has a bigger groove and a smaller so as to fit well to the requirements of space and the wire section.

Objectives The purpose of this project is to create an economic and versatile tool for soldering. Pieces of silver paper allowed to be attacked on the faces in contact with the wires. Results You've finally an object that makes your much the welding operation even in confined spaces where you can not use the base with pliers.
I hope it is very useful to carry out your projects.

title: Magsafe Power Adapter Cable Saver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
21st March 2016 --- Updated:
I have Dugout, polished, revamped a website I have been lying there for almost two years. Finally, I had spent sometimes puzzled it up. Hope it looks simple and illustrative.
Please visit my new site -- http://www.designique.co for all MagSavior Products and my new Google Cardboard Variant (pending google certify)

Have you ever encountered your MagSafe power adapter for the MacBook was blown away suddenly one day and you have to buy another one? Have you noted that the joining part of the adapter and the cable have a kink inside? That is because the negative shielding has worn off. (See my photo attached!) Thus, will create lots of electrical stress onto the adapter and one day you will hear the "POP" sound.
If your MagSafe is still working and wish to prolong the life span before googling "How to fix MagSafe adapter".
I have made this little clip that is able to strengthen the flexible end of the joining part between the cable and the adapter.
I am pretty happy about it and wish to share with everyone out there and hope everyone have a Safe Magsafe. Updates: Check out my FaceBook Page:
https://www.facebook.com/DesigniqueCo

Print ABS with infill 15 - 20%, shell =2 and layer height 0.2. Please scale 1.02 as the fitting will be too tight with original size. Adjust according because i've found that my 80W and 65W adapters are different in cable thickness.   
I have attached photos to explain on the installation of the cable saver.  
PLA might be too brittle ...   
btw, the thru hole on the flank is a 4mm dia and you can use a Cable tie to tighten the grip.  
Do give me some feedback if you have any. Thanks :P

comments.text: I had trouble with this one, there is no gap, it is all filled in, I will try to saw it apart to be able to use it.
comments.author: mwendt

comments.text: Try using 1 shell. This was my first design and have to print it right up. Hence, when the nozzle reached to the top, it get stickier. set the makerbot to 1 shell and try to print 2 at once, so the nozzle will travel to the next one while cooling down the first. Something like creating prime pillar.
comments.author: mwendt

comments.text: I could use one of these. Would you glue the green plastic to the white power adapter?
comments.author: barnett

comments.text: For me, I will stick a 3M double size adhesive in between (I used 3M scotch 468MP, they use these in car dashboard) and use a cable tie go thru the 4mm hole and secured it. That will prevent it from any whopping and rocking.  One more thing. I am not too sure that the current new magsafe power adapters are still the same size. So you've got to resize a little. Generally, 1.02 should be alright. Be careful while to ply open and push in the cable. I am hoping to make a smooth groove underneath. Thanks and do give me some feedback so I could improve on it.

Customizable thing with four columns located at the corners of a rectangle and mounted on a base. You can specify the location of the columns, the size of the base, etc. The default data in the Customizer file creates a 120 x 80 mm base for a Raspberry Pi 2 Model B board. The 2.5 mm mounting holes for the board work well with #4 sheetmetal screws. Adjust the hole size so that the screws you will be using self-tap by cutting their own threads in the column hole. (You may need to experiment a bit; the exact size seems to depend on the printer you are using and the type of plastic you are extruding.) If you want more post options, or a more complicated arrangement of posts, see my "Polygon Columns with Holes and a Twist" Thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1370889) which features individual positioning of up to 10 columns (and has uses a lot more parameters).

remixed_from.author: profhankd
remixed_from.title: Minolta SR/MC/MD Lens To Canon FL/FD/FDn Body Adapter

title: Kiev 10/15 Lens To Canon FL/FD/FDn Body Adapter

description.text: The Kiev 10 was the first Soviet-built 35mm SLR with automatic exposure. It did this using an internal linkage for the body to control the lens aperture -- there is no aperture control ring on the lens. The same lens mount was used by the Kiev 15 TEE, but nothing else, and the internal aperture linkage makes adapting to another mount problematic. In http://www.instructables.com/id/Using-Kiev-10Kiev-15-Lenses-On-Digital-Cameras/ , I showed a way to hack an adapter to provide a mount with an aperture control ring for Kiev 10/15 lenses, but it was awkward. Instead, the adapter shown here allows Kiev 10/15 lenses to mount and focus to infinity on standard Canon FL/FD/FDn body mounts while still providing aperture control using a less-than-20-degree twist of the lens in its mount. Why bother? Well, Kiev 10/15 lenses are optically excellent while being smaller than their brothers in other mounts -- and often are available much more cheaply. With this adapter, you can even use Kiev 10/15 lenses on an FD Lens Turbo with your Sony NEX. Of course, this is a true adapter not a mount conversion, so you don't harm your potentially collectible Kiev 10/15 lenses by using it. Be warned that this adapter does not lock, although the ones I've printed are all very firm fits. Use it at your own risk. NOTE: if you are using this to mount on a Sony E-mount body, there is now a complete adapter for that posted as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1464062 .

There are overhangs in this print, and you'll probably have to use a pair of tweezers to remove a few dropped threads and work the part on an FL/FD flange a little to get things operating smoothly, but it's really not bad. There is an overhang to engage the Kiev 10/15 aperture tab, and that will also no doubt have some dropped threads too, but leaving that a little ragged just helps it engage the tab -- no harm done.  A little filing to break the leading edges on the printed Kiev flanges may help it operate more smoothly.  
Ours were printed on a MakerGear M2 in PLA with 0.25mm extrusion and between 20%-40% fill. Use a light-blocking filament -- ideally a black that gets its color from carbon black particles rather than dye, because most synthetic dyes are transparent in the NIR band, and camera sensors will record NIR.  
There are two indented holes on the part: these show the start and end top positions for the FL/FD mount. I like to paint these red using a toothpick and a little red paint.   
So, how does this work? Push the adapter on the FL/FD mount with the rightmost red dot at the top, then turn it right until the second red dot is at the top. Take the Kiev lens facing top up and turn it to the left until the first screw is facing up; push it into the adapter and turn it right until the top is up. The aperture lever should have engaged such that rotating the lens through about 20 degrees in the mount will open and close the aperture without dismounting the lens.  
The photos show the Kiev 10/15->FL/FD adapter on a lens, the adapter mounting a lens on a Canon FTb body, and a photo taken with that lens using my FD Lens Turbo and Sony NEX-7.

description.text: My traceable shape things can be printed out very quickly with little plastic. I made these designs to be simple and intuitive so that anybody would be able to re-size them as needed.

Printer:

CraftBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

optimum

Infill:

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. As can be seen from the photo, an increased infill may be helpful as well.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For this project I started out with the geometric shape titled 'roof' on TinkerCAD. To get the triangle shape, I rotated it on axis. I then adjusted the height to 2mm in order to get a strong but minimal thing. Next I adjusted it using Shift+click to 120x120mm so that the thing would be large enough to use, as well as fit on a variety of printers including MakerBots. Next I used alt+click to make another triangle. Then I re-sized it using shift+click to 110mm and moved it to the center of the original triangle. Then, using the hide and group features, I had a final product.

Objective The purpose of this project is to help kids see and learn shapes by being hands-on. Using my tracers kids will be able to interact with shapes by being able to trace, cut, and color them. Audience The intended audience is kids 3+ with adult supervision, although these would be good for all ages to keep in there craft materials for when they need a perfect geometric shape. Preparation
  • Teachers wishing to modify the size of their own triangles will need to have access to a computer with internet access and be logged on to a free TinkerCAD account.
  • Tinkercad is easier to use with a mouse than with a tablet or trackpad, so computer mice are recommended.
  • No previous 3D design experience is required for the students, although familiarity with Tinkercad would be helpful.
  • Kids should have access to crayons/color pencils, safety scissors, and be supervised at all times.
    • Step 1: Adjust size Depending on your project and/or needs, you may need to adjust the size of the object. Simply download the thing from here and upload it to www.tinkercad.com. Next, press shift+click on one of the corners to adjust the size. Remember that you can adjust the snap in the bottom right corner which will allow you to be more or less accurate. Step 2: Print! Check out the beginning of this project for recommended settings. It would be good to let the kid(s) in on this process, but remember that there are lots of hot pieces on a 3D printer. Step 3: Trace Either have your kid(s) hold down the shapes and trace in or outside them, or alternatively tape the shapes down. Step 4: Cut Assist you kid(s) in cutting out the shapes. Using safety scissors is advised, and using non-straight scissors (like the ones that cut in wavy lines) could add more fun. Step 5: Color If you had the kid(s) trace inside of the thing, they could have just colored it all the way in already. Nonetheless, you can use this part of the project to also teach them about colors. Results The kids can use this to learn about shapes, colors, and scissor safety. This will give kids a good head start for their academic careers!

Teach music theory and composition with musical dice! This 7 sided dice has the notes out of a scale on it. All songs are made up of notes in a scale – the scale, and chords that go with it, turn random notes generated by the music maker dice into amazing themes and songs. In order to compose a song:
  • Choose a musical scale or key signature for your song, and then create the music maker dice that has the key signature that you need.
  • Start your song on a dominate note in your key signature.
  • Roll your musical dice, and use the notes that come up to create a melody. So long as all of your notes come out of the same key signature it will sound great!
  • Choose your favorite note sequence for your repeating theme.
  • Most songs end where they begin – pull that melody back to the first note you started on!
    • In order to teach music theory: Roll the music maker dice, and then find the note on a clef.
    Roll the music maker dice, and play the note that comes up on your instrument.
    Roll the dice, and play a chord to go with that note! Can you play the minor, major, 6th, 7th etc. chords? See example you tubes where we made music with random notes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QCZ183DC6fc&feature=gp-n-y&google_comment_id=z125gbthapf1wx12v22iv3xyfpi0hhef3 See also: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ifty4emR930

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

high detail

Notes: When printing, lay it flat, and no print support structure will be needed. If you scale the size down too much it might be a little hard to read the text – a larger sized dice will probably work the best. The letters will show up better in lighter colored filaments.

Inventor Tutorial! The music maker dice was created using AutoDesk’s Inventor Software, and then exported to an STL file. Free Inventor software for students and educators:
http://www.autodesk.com/education/free-software/inventor-professional The Music maker was created by extruding 7 sided polygons. Because of the odd number of sides that is needed in this dice, a central polygon was created so that when the dice lands only one musical note is sitting on top. Letters were added with the text tool, and extruded into the axial dice faces. The key signatures that match the notes are inscribed in the ends of the dice. Each set of notes can be matched to two different scales – a minor and a major. Create first polygon, and dimension to desired size. Extrude first polygon Create an inner rotated polygon: Extrude Inner polygon Create the top polygon: Extrude all polygons to the same height: Write centered bold large text on each side corresponding to the notes in your scale: Rotate your text, then copy and paste it onto all of the other sides. Double click on each of the sides to change the letters to what you would like them to be, then cut the letters and designs into your piece.

description.text: My traceable shape things can be printed out very quickly with little plastic. I made these designs to be simple and intuitive so that anybody would be able to re-size them as needed.

Printer:

CraftBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

optimum

Infill:

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. As can be seen from the photo, an increased infill may be helpful as well.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For this project I started out with the geometric shape titled 'box' on TinkerCAD. I then adjusted the height to 2mm in order to get a strong but minimal thing. Next I adjusted it using Shift+click to 120x120mm so that the thing would be large enough to use, and fit on a variety of printers including MakerBots. Next I used alt+click to make another shape. Then I re-sized it using shift+click to 110mm and moved it to the center of the original square. Then, using the hide and group features, I had a final product.

Objective The purpose of this project is to help kids see and learn shapes by being hands-on. Using my tracers kids will be able to interact with shapes by being able to trace, cut, and color them. Audience The intended audience is kids 3+ with adult supervision, although these would be good for all ages to keep in there craft materials for when they need a perfect geometric shape. Preparation
  • Teachers wishing to modify the size of their own triangles will need to have access to a computer with internet access and be logged on to a free TinkerCAD account.
  • Tinkercad is easier to use with a mouse than with a tablet or trackpad, so computer mice are recommended.
  • No previous 3D design experience is required for the students, although familiarity with Tinkercad would be helpful.
  • Kids should have access to crayons/color pencils, safety scissors, and be supervised at all times.
    • Step 1: Adjust size Depending on your project and/or needs, you may need to adjust the size of the object. Simply download the thing from here and upload it to www.tinkercad.com. Next, press shift+click on one of the corners to adjust the size. Remember that you can adjust the snap in the bottom right corner which will allow you to be more or less accurate. Step 2: Print! Check out the beginning of this project for recommended settings. It would be good to let the kid(s) in on this process, but remember that there are lots of hot pieces on a 3D printer. Step 3: Trace Either have your kid(s) hold down the shapes and trace in or outside them, or alternatively tape the shapes down. Step 4: Cut Assist you kid(s) in cutting out the shapes. Using safety scissors is advised, and using non-straight scissors (like the ones that cut in wavy lines) could add more fun. Step 5: Color If you had the kid(s) trace inside of the thing, they could have just colored it all the way in already. Nonetheless, you can use this part of the project to also teach them about colors. Results The kids can use this to learn about shapes, colors, and scissor safety. This will give kids a good head start for their academic careers!

Notes: I used coarse quality in matter control for a faster result. did not go wrong
Remixed it to provide a magnet, and a slip-fit for changing bits

I printed a few of the original http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137367 handles for hex bits I use all the time.
They are a very tight fit and will probably never come out. But I wanted at least one handle to be a universal holder. So, I edited a cavity in the bottom of the hex to hold a small neodymium magnet, 3x6 mm.
I have a whole bunch of these, hacked from a child's toy magnet construction set. Different sets have different diameter magnets, and some thicker and thinner. The fit had to be a little sloppy so the bits can slip in and out. Surprisingly, scaling up to 105% was not enough. Perhaps that's because I test-printed only one handle at a time, and the print was really hot and soft, and a lot of shrinkage was the result.
(Maybe it's this brand new spool of filament.. i dunno.) Anyway, I jumped to 110% (X and Y) and after cooling it is a nice loose fit, similar to a commercial holder. I "paused" the print to insert the magnet, smooshing a couple strands of soft plastic over it, and that worked OK, but the 3x6 magnet is small enough to drop through the hex-hole and might also be secured with super glue or 5-min epoxy. Who knows what will happen to the fit if you print more than one. All I know is small, thick parts like these cool to different dimensions when more or fewer are printed on this Afinia. Re-scaling up or down might be needed. Afinia default setting.. (medium speed, 0.3mm Z, medium fill.)

title: Wanhao i3 offset Y axis Bearing Block

description.text:
These bearing blocks were designed so you can use an aftermarket (Prusa i3) style bed which is much thicker than the stock flimsy Duplicator i3 bed. These block have the needed 15mm offset spacing required to fit the smaller spaced rods on the Wanhao i3. You will also have to raise your endstop up so the new style carriage will clear. This is the bed that is currently being used on our personal Wanhao i3.
http://tinyurl.com/upgradedi3bed The 16mm sized file is for the IGUS RJM-01-08 Drylin bearing
The 15mm sized file is for the stock bearings AND the direct replacement IGUS Drylin RJ4JP-01-08
*The 15mmL is for those that want to use the 45mm LM8LUU Bearings **Make sure to install the 2 M4 nuts under the bearing BEFORE you secure the bearing down with a ziptie..

Adjusted for printing with slic3r. BODY:
I cut body in 1/2 so no supports needed. Eye hex and crank holes were made larger. Clean up the body half's & front 3 crank holes first (1/16" bit). Glue the eye section with crazy glue, then glue the tail next. Install the crank. Glue near the crank holes & wing pivots although this is not necessary. The crank was formed with a 1 mm paper clip & needle nose pliers. The offset was made with a 1/8" nose, the journal was made with a 3/16" nose. Center offset is 1/4". File the wing pivots to be around 2.8 mm in diameter. Being this is not intended to fly, I used a second 1 mm paper clip for linkage and hand crank. Check the tail hole for fit up and adjust as required. You can used a #57 drill bit if necessary. WINGS:
Pivot hole was relocate & legs made larger for more strength. Slow the speed to 15 to 20% when getting to the wing legs. 10% 1,3,3,3 with 1 raft. Clean the pivot hole with a 1/8" drill bit & inside of legs with a file. I used a timer to go off when 3 minuets were left so as to not forget to slow the print speed. The material above the wing pivot point is about l.00 mm and fragile. You will have to make a new one if broken. LEGS:
The legs have been modified for this build. The body tail & crank section has a relief for easier leg fit and slid into place. The plus leg will give a raked look if used for the back one or cut the front leg. Glue when a good balance is achieved if you like. Full instructions can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:951687 Very nice build by thinkpool. Will be waiting for the next one. Please add you location to you profile. I'm always wondering?

If your like me you may have jumped in pretty hard right off the bat with additional MBI products such as the filament spindle boxes.  After running a few 2 pound spools through them on kitchen turn tables (lazy Susans, sorry to any Susan's reading this) it started to become a large pain de-stacking my bot and top spindle box just to get to the bottom box for a change out.  So I just wanted to jot down a few notes as I rigged my setup for quicker filament change outs as well as adapting the boxes for different filament vendor spools and sizes.

Here is a list of cheap tricks I pulled to make horizontal spool life easier: Remove 4 top tabs from acrylic front door Remove 2 left side tabs from acrylic front door Remove 2 right side tabs from acrylic front door Remove and store the 2 lower M3 bolts from acrylic front door Take the 2 top bolts, wind a nut 1/3 the way up on each bolt, insert them through the top of the acrylic front door (see pics) and then add a nut to the backside of the acrylic door and tighten the nuts against each other Slot the acrylic door in the bottom 4 tab slots and use the protruding top bolts (now handles) to close the door For rigidity insert the 2 side bolts as door locks Additional Options Try my spool plate and adapter to widen your spindle box filament spool options: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13755 Slap an additional two MBI 2 pound spool holders on your bot using: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7105 (I have 2 spindle boxes so I mounted them on my top box (see pics)) Don't forget some spool guards, there are lots to choose from but these clear the MBI spindle box internals pretty nice: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6952 Mega happy horizontal filament spooling to all!

description.text: Print The double 18650 holder and use some bolts and nuts for battery contacts. cable shoes (or copper wire) to connect it to the button and 510 connector. The lid is slide in and the tolerance is 1% if you need a bigger or larger tolerance just scale it. use superglue and glue the battery holder into the box mod AFTER YOU HAVE PLACED THE BUTTON AND CONNECTORS! make sure there is space for inserting the batteries.. the button i used is a large 22mm automotive push-button(from a local biltema) rated for 20Amps. the cells must be protected or else you must add a fuse or something else. for safety when not using your device you should remove your rba/rda so that it doesnt fire in your pocket or your bag. I used my cells in parallel because they had very low drain. my coil resistance is 0.75ohms. you could add a mosfet and switch inside the mod for extra safety(you wont have to remove your rba/rda all the time for safety)

description.text: "Administrating control over countless worlds throughout the Multiverse, the militaristic police-state known as the Trans-Universal Dominion has brought peace and stability to those willing to comply." These characters and vehicles were modeled for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download! This page will provide you with rules cards for the models we make (they're included with the pictures and compiled in a zip file), but remember that Wayfarer Tactics gives you the means to make your own rules too, so just look at this as a resource (it's nice to have a bunch of pre-made stuff). These characters are pulled from the pages of our tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder, and are compatible with that game as well (as well as any other RPG or wargame for which you want to use them). We're only including the "split" versions of the models here (you'll need some glue), but if you're brave/skilled enough to print the full versions with support material, they're all compiled in this monster of a Thing. Like the full version model compendium, we'll keep this updated as we make more cards/models. If you want to print 28mm scale versions of any of these models, just scale them up by 166.6%. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

author: dutchmogul

description.text:
An openscad library to create complex objects easily Ship or airplane hulls or models thereof are often constructed from frames which define beams and the external shape of the hull. This technique is also useful for construction in openscad, particularly in 3d printing. I have been using this technique manually for quite some time, constructing my frames one by one, placing them and connecting them using the openscad hull command. This library attempts to somewhat automate the task. All you need to do is define your frames (size, offset, rotation) in a list and pass this list to a library module. The library module constructs the hull shape from the list. If you want to change something, you can easily do so by adjusting the parameters in the list, whithout any further code changes. I have found this technique quite useful for both simple and complex objects. For example, the complex double-crossbeam connected by longitudinal beam in example_complex02.scad was made with just 19 lines/frames for half an arm, which was then mirrored. That ist, for such a complex structure, almost no openscad coding is required, just define your 19 frames, call the beam_multi module, and you are done. Fine-tuning is simple by modifying the frame params. No translations, unions etc. required, just change the width, height and offsets of individual frames. For complex structures such as this one, I usually develop the structure from start to end, frame after frame and always retain control over the process. usage: just copy beams.scad and one of the example scad files into the same directory and start coding in scad. For startes, you only need to adjust the frame params in the example file. If you want to add more frames, just copy the last line in the params array, adjust height and width and increase the y-offset in comparision to the copied line. As a best practise, I usually arrange the frames along the y axis. In that case, you only need to set width and height for the frames and make sure the y offsets are increasing monotonously from line to line. Adjust x offset to move the frames to the sides, e.g. half width for centered frames. For ramps between frames, use two frames with some y offset and different width or height. For steps between frames, use two consecutive frames with different width or height at the same y-offset. see https://github.com/Stemer114/openscad_beams
for latest version and new examples

title: Kossel XL end stop switch holder

description.text: I bought parts from Robotdigg for a Kossel XL. I designed this end stop for that printer. The frame is build from 2020 extruded aluminium and has lineair rails. The lineair rail fits a few mm into the end stop holder. the calibration screw of the carriage is level to the switch.

Some of the part I bought for this printer:
  • 2020 aluminum extrusion for Kossel XL
  • Metal Corner for Kossel of 2020 Profile
  • MGN12-1H-L600 Linear Rail and Carriage for Kossel XL
  • Carriage for open ended belt
  • Pre-assembly T nuts for 2020 aluminum profile
  • Endstop Subminiature Switch SS-5GL
  • 3pin 1M Long Endstop Cables w/ Dupont Connector
    • Parts needed to mount the switch:
  • 3x printed end stop holder
  • 6x M2.5 x 20 bolt
  • 6x M2 nut
  • 3x M3 x 20
  • 3x M3 T-nut
    • Use some Loctite on the thread of the bolts.

Venturi Design This was designed in Tinkercad with entry and exit angles based on Escbach, Handbook of Engineering Fundamentals, 3rd Edition, 1975. This was made as an alternative to a submersible pump due to its properties that allow it to pass debris.

Project: Adjustible Venturi Objectives: I expect students to learn alternative ways to create suction and lift allowing them to have a better grasp of fluid dynamics.
◦Audiences: List the grades, ages, or skill levels that would be appropriate for this Project.
◦Preparation: Motive source, substrate to be moved and collection container. they will also require 3/8'" I.D. tubing.
◦Steps: The first design proved that the motive could not create suction due to not having enough direction. In MK2 a separate motive nozzle was added for calibration and control of flow. I highly recommend a brief introduction to venture design before the lab.
◦Results: I run this at 0.017 mpa and achieve approximately 4 gallons of fluid movement daily. This can of course be increase with more motive though I would print in in 100% infill for stability. This has proven to be a great resource for an indoor greenhouse that is a recirculating deep water culture allowing fresh produce year round in the northern environment.

title: Scotty Dogz
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Scotty Dogz are a small easy one piece print with a springy moving head and tail. At standard scale they measure only 50mm long / 38mm high / 10mm thick so use very little filament and print in very little time. 
Do not use support... it's not required but Raft is recommended for ease of removing the print from your build plate and to make sure you don't damage the thin flat springs that print internally and make the head and tail... springy. 
These print really well on Replicator 2's and 5th Generation Replicators. As soon as the Raft is removed the head and tail should spring forward and backwards. 
This should print fine in PLA on most accurate well set up machines that bridge well and using a good slicing application. However, there are a few machines and slicing apps that have issues dealing with fine clearances and the internal surfaces necessary to print things that move.
Print lots in your favourite colors... great fun 'pets' to have around the place and sure to be popular as little gifts
Please refer to the images and print settings for additional information and post images of your Scotty Dogs. . 
Note: If you like Scotty Dogz check out the rest of my fun and practical designs... and post images of your prints!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard in PLA

Infill:

2 Shells / 35% infill recommended

Notes: Use Raft for ease of removal and to ensure your Scotty Dogz aren't damaged during removal from the build plate. Don't use support as that could cause the internal flat springs to be fused in place which would stop all movement. Recommend using 35% infill.... this still won't use a lot of filament as they are a small print. .
Carefully remove the Raft and your Scotty Dogz tail and head should be springy right away....

title: involute gear two rows of teeth - PowerWheel Ride on Toy

description.text:
I needed a replacement gear for my son's Powerwheel ride on toy. I couldn't find a good customizable gear having the two rows of teeth. So I took the code from the Customizable Involute Spur Gear by atartanian and basically copied it twice. I translated the top gear to go up the height of the bottom gear to combined them together. As my son would say, I'm a "noob" at OpenSCAD, but this gear seems to be working well as a replacement for my Powerwheels. (Not sure why the top gear isn't showing up in the customizer for me, but feel free to view the source and copy it to your own editor if you'd like). Hope it helps someone else. Bottom Gear settings are the variables starting with the numbers 0 or 1 (eg. 01, 02, 10, 11, 12).
Top Gear settings are the variables starting with the number 2 (eg. 20, 21, 22)

title: 8 cubes in one AMF file for multicolor print head

description.text:
This is simply one 10mm cube that I duplicated 8 times vertically, at same XY, but incremented the Z location by 10 each time. Then I imported all 8 stl's into Slic3r and saved it as this AMF file. So when you bring it into Repetier or another 3d printer controlling software, you can assign different colors to the different objects within this group. You can also delete cube 8, 7 , 6 etc if you want to make a shorter stick, as seen in photo.
Or you can scale this group either to make real short but still 10x10 in the XY, to let you create real thin layers of color like the photo of the rainbow cube. I scaled 0.6 in the X and Y and 0.8 in the Z for most of those color sticks to speed up the print.
You can see that I used it to test my color output from my DiamondHotend. I am using RYB (Red Yellow Blue) color combination, which means I don't have the full gamut of colors that a CYM (cyan yellow magenta ) would give. I am simply using the filament I have for now, I'll move to CYM later, as it looks like CYM gives a slightly fuller spectrum.
So bring this into Repetier and you'll see that if you have at least 8 virtual extruders, you can assign 8 different colors to the objects in this group.
If this all is confusing check out this http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Repetier_Color_Mixing
Bottom line is I used Blender to create a 10mm cube, and saved it off 8 times at different heights as .stl. Then I imported all 8 into Slic3r , and from there saved as this AMF.
If you have repetier installed, you already have Slic3r, just you need to go create a launch shortcut for it.

description.text:
This is a case for the Pocket Operator series of synthesizers made by Teenage Engineering. Its main features are:
  • Keys move freely
  • LEDs are still visible
  • Audio sockets accessible with standard sized rubberized jacks
  • Possible to keep the break-away hanger if wanted
  • Possible to keep the wire-stand attached
  • No glue or screws
  • Printable with low-end FDM printer
    • Source files are created with FreeCAD 0.15. Note: A version of case, buttons and light guides optimized for SLS/SLA printing also available at shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/cdb Compatible with these things:
  • PO-20 symbol buttons: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1410100
  • Numbered buttons: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1617681
  • Light guides (difficult!): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2091660
  • Mic Frontplate: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779257
    • Compatible remixes:
  • Light guide buttons by Axeman72: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2090105
    • Update (Jan. 30th 2018)
    Added microphone holes to the front plate (Case_Front_full_v6_mic_rotated.stl) for the new PO series (PO-32, 33, 35).

title: Battery caps for AA, AAA, 18650 and other cell types

description.text:
This "thing" was inspired by Mobilow's accu caps (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:115711), since I also always carry spare batteries with me - for my camera, my eTrex, my MP3, ... The challenge was to find a design that a) would firmly hold all batteries of the same type, even if they are a tiny bit larger or smaller than the norm value, and b) that would be easily customizable for different battery types and an arbitrary MxN array of battery cells.
The solution to the first problem was to add flexible "friction winglets" between the cells, which result in a firm grip of the battery cells over a reasonable variation in diameters. This way I can carry the "capped" batteries in my pocket all day without any fear that the caps will fall off by accident. The needed configurability is built into the .scad file, which contains a generic module CellCaps() and for each type of batteries a small module which calls CellCaps() with the corresponding size parameters. Normally, two identical caps are used to safely store and transport a set of batteries. However, single larger arrays (e.g. 6x4 AAs) can also be used as storage trays. The .stl files provided are for the standards AA, AAA batteries, as well as for the 18650 Li-Ion/Li-Po cells. For each type I have included linear 2x, 3x , 4x arrays as well as a 2x2-array. But it's straight forward to adapt the .scad file for any other cylindrical cell type or array layout. Update 2014-09-09: If you are looking for a battery holder to provide battery power to some electronic project, check out my flexing battery holder with integrated spring.

I printed my battery caps in ABS (because of the better elasticity of the winglets) on my RepRap using H=.35mm/W=.56mm layers.  
If you want to rebuild a particular .stl file from the .scad file, make sure to uncomment the corresponding module call at the end of the file.

Capacitive sensor mount designed for Prusa i3 Hephestos.
Might work with other prusa i3, but only tested with hephestos. Should be printed in ABS because of the extruder temperature, but i printed it in PLA nad also works fine (i guess because the air flow keeps it cool). Tested with a chinesse 8$ capacitive sensor, that has 12V input and 6v output, so it doesn't need voltage divider, and the hole is ~20mm aprox. If it is a bit loose, the sensor can be tighted up with the nuts and washers it comes with. If you have any questions or doubts about adding a capacitive sensor to a prusa i3 with Ramps 1.4 and Marlin, you are free to ask. ( you can also email me at [email protected]) Unluckly Meshlab messed with the measures and converted it from milimeters to inches... needs to be scaled or exported a new .stl from the .dae or .skp (If using Simplify3D, it auto scales it)

This is a combination lock container with 1000 possible combinations. Inside is a space large enough to fit a key, some money, or whatever you feel like hiding away. The top of the container has an eyelet for attaching a keychain, and also makes it easy to open once the combination has been entered. Video: https://youtu.be/XYfcUvGQVMg In the project files there are files for #0 - #9, pick the three digits that you would like to be in your combination and print those out. The order you put them on when you assemble it determines the order of the code. A note - obviously a 3D printed lock such as this one could be forced open by breaking, this is nonetheless still a very neat object to print.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Self-Made

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: The only part that needs support material is part "L2", I had success using the 'Pillars' option in Slic3r.

Assembly Once you have the parts printed, assemble the number rings on the main body. Make sure that you have the numbers facing up, and have them in the correct order for your code. The top cap can then be carefully glued on, making sure not to accidently bond any other parts together.
This was designed in Autodesk Inventor 2016 and AutoCAD 2015.

description.text:
UPDATE I changed too many variables between my first print that works for now but cracked (pictured) and my second print. I had increased the inside diameter and the wall thickness of the model and the number of perimeters and infill of the print. It snapped into place without cracking but it took a lot of effort and the velcro loop broke off. I'm trying a third time with the modified file but with only two perimeters and 30% infill.
Follow up The 2 perimeter, 30% infill worked well. Pretty hard to snap on. I'm wondering if the first version with 3 perimeters and 30% infill would work... hmmm. The clamp that holds one of my Polaris pool vacuum filter bags in place broke. The clips come with the bags and I usually have a stash of old ones from when the bag shreds before the clip breaks. Unfortunately I'm fresh out and the bag has a little life left in it. The pictures are from my first attempt. It was printed as a test with PLA, 2 perimeters and 15% infill. It cracked when I snapped it around the hose post. Version 2 has a slightly larger inside diameter to ease the stress on the part when snapping into place and I'm going to print it with 60% infill and 3 perimeters. Earlier this summer I threw a calibration print (PLA) into the pool to see how it held up. After three months the color had faded slightly but it was still strong and had not delaminated at all. This is the first work focused part that I've printed with the intent of leaving in the pool for a long period of time. Has anyone else had any luck with prints long term in pools?

This model is a marker organizer. This can help  learning because you can use the dry-erase board to teach in multiple colors without losing the markers. It also helps to keep the room more organized to keep it a neater learning environment. This was originally made for Mrs. Reno because she always loves to keep her markers very organized. It is used by simply placing the markers in the colored cups, and the eraser in the bigger cup. There is a slit taken out of the side of the eraser cup to make it easier to get the eraser out.

The design was created being able to easily fit a dry erase marker and eraser, however, our 3D printer was not able to print something that big. We had to scale the model down a little bit when printing. If we had a bigger printer, then the model can be printed actual size and work as a marker holder.
I had to redesign this many times before I got the one that I ended up with now. The size was always too big. Then I got the design that I came up with now, and added the eraser component.

Braille is a blind people writing method and this project use 3Dprinting and Brille "6points" alphabet to learn (Italian) geography.

Software For this project i used:
  • Autocad
  • Tinkercad
  • Cura
  • Gimp
    • Steps I sought a picture of Political Italian Map and I downloaded it. I elaborated it with Gimp and imported in autocad with "Import Raster" tool.
    After I designed the bordes of each regions with "Spline" tool. At the same time I chose "6 Points" Braille Code after a research of writing codes for blind people. I found a online converter at http://www.translatum.gr/converter/braille.htm In Autocad I designed 20 tags with names of differents regions in Braille Code I exstruded the bordes designed with "extrude" tool of Autocad 3D.
    After I export in stl format and adjusted dimension of shapes and tags in Cura. Finaly I composed each regions shape with tag in tinkercad.
    Here there was the design studio for assembling whitouth interference between tags of differents shapes.

Objective the purpose of this project is to help blind kids to learn the Italian geography by touching the shapes of 3Dprinted regions. Audience Every body could play with puzzle game of italian regions but it was created for blind kids from 4+ Preparation -Teachers take 2 or more team of kids and explain that there are shapes of italian regions with tags in Braille.
-teachers explain that it's a puzzle and could start asking what are the regions that confine with a determinates ones. Steps -Pupils try to compose puzzle touching, asking and comparing with others kids and teachers.
-taechers say stop when time finish or when puzzle is completed.
-Teachers declere winners Results Kids enjoyed!!! because they are speaking with us and with teachers after an manual experience. Kids are learned!!! Italian geograpy, now he can says where are located the differents regions and are touched geograpy shape of Italy. Teachers can invite higer pupils to create an other geograpy puzzle with blind students helps.

description.text: This project was designed to help students learn the placement of all of the elements on the Periodic Table. I wanted to design something that could not be done with paper. I saw online that there where four new elements added to the Periodic Table of Elements and thought that an Elements "puzzle" would be perfect to design for this challenge. I did not have time to print the whole project and still enter in time but I did do two test prints that show that everything will work, last two pictures.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

  • If you have a printer that is 6x6x6 inches then you can scale this down to .60 and it will fit.

  • If you would like to color code the pieces like in picture two, then i would recommend using netfab to cut the pieces apart

This was very interesting to design purely because there where so many elements to design and write the abbreviation for. pieces:
For every every piece I used the text tool in 123d design and wrote the abbreviation for the element that the piece would become. I would then use the extrusion tool to give the text a third dimension. After that i would center the text in the middle of the piece then move it up and use it as a cutting tool to add the text to the piece. I continued this process for ever element. Board:
I first design the shape of the board.I then made a copy of all the pieces and scaled them up to 1.05 and used the pieces as a cutting tool to add the holes for the pieces. After that i added the text to the top. Finally i used the sketch tool to draw a dovetail design that i would then use to cut the board in half giving the board dovetail joints to connect the two pieces after printing.

description.header: Project: Learn the Periodic Table of Elements
description.text:
Objectives
  • learn the Periodic Table of Elements
    • Audiences
  • students in grades 8-10 would be ideal for this project
  • when the teacher/school decides this project would be appropriate
    • Preparation
  • students will be expected to learn about the Periodic Table of Elements before attempting this project
    • Step 1
  • introduce the project by starting to teach about the Periodic Table of Elements
    • Step 2
  • have students practice with the 'puzzle'
    • Step 3
  • have students complete the Puzzle and grade it
    • Result
  • students should have learned the placement of all the elements in the Periodic Table of Elements by the end of this project
  • teachers could give two points per piece, one for putting the piece in the right area and one for putting the piece in its exact spot

This model is a bookmark. As you can see, it is not your average bookmark. This bookmark actually points to the word you left off on if you stop in the middle of a page. How it works is, you would insert the pointer into the toothed section of the bookmark with the ledges of the pointer facing the teeth. This allows, or should allow the pointer to slide up and down the bookmark. The other section of the bookmark is so that you can hook it over the page so it stays in place. This helps learning because when students are reading books, they don’t have to waste time finding where they left off. It keeps readers more organized. This was made for mainly students and either reading or language arts teachers.

da Vinci 1.0 AiO

The pointer does indeed slide up and down the bookmark. It is very wide for a bookmark and might slide out. However, it does work the way it should.

This is an project i am working on for 1,5 years already - it is an OpenSource/OpenHardware Streaming Device, which is using compressed ogg/vorbis to stream Audio to an IceCast2 Server and it will include a Mini-Sighttpd-Server on its own too. On nice thing about it - that we will print the lightguides for the LEDs with our Pursa Mendel using transparent PLA :) ... not any more => I switched to a hot glue technique which produces better results http://oggstreamer.wordpress.com/2012/04/03/oggstreamer-12-frontpanels-produced/ Its got a blog: http://oggstreamer.wordpress.com/
A short description can be found here: http://oggstreamer.wordpress.com/about/
And the latest mechanical design can be found here: http://sourceforge.net/p/oggstreamer/mcad/

I am currently producing a small batch of 12 pcs. The mechanical work is already done. There were small modifications to the Case. The Drilling for the Poti got bigger (7mm => 9mm) a small (2mm) drilling was added for the Poti "Nose". And a small detail of the fixation hole for the cinch-plugs. It moved slightly (0.5mm) towards the left.
The current Version of the mechanics is Rev 1 (Draft 25)

The idea is to have one of these devices at each station and to have remote monitoring stations be able to listen to the activity selectively.  While each station will have a PC associated with it, the local sound card is tied up running the station.  I could always add a second sound card, but there is the possibility of software conflicts.  A device such as yours would greatly simplify the each station.

title: Hoshizaki Ice Machine Evaporator Cleaning Block

description.text: This is a great tool for those working on hoshizaki Ice Machines, it works very well.

2) 3M x 23 SS Hex Cap Screw
2) M4 SS Flat Washer
2) M3x8-5 Brass Knurl Inserts
1) Wooden Paint Stick (preferably a fully wooded stick to as to help prevent damage to the evaporator surface)
1) a supply of 4x6 (you will need to cut about 1/4 off) scotch bright pads

1) Print the IM Cleaner Body V2 standing and either 100% infill and 200 microns OR, using a dual process', print the bottom half (just under the threaded section for the pole) at 30% and the rest (the threads) at 100% at 200 microns
2) Print the IM Cleaner Clamp V2 laying on it's small side (Recessed Holes Up) at 100% infill with no supports.

Using a soldering Iron, melt the Brass Knurl Inserts into the  IM Cleaner Body V2. Making sure you have a small lip of plastic over the top of the Inserts (helps keep them from pulling out)
Install the SS Flat Washer onto the SS Hex Cap Screw, run them through the IM Cleaner Clamp V2 and into the cooled Brass Knurl Inserts.

Most likely you will need to cut about 1/4 off the end of the pad, but you should do a dry run just to make sure.
The easiest way to load a scotch bright pad is to make sure the screws are fully extended and just holding on by a few threads (gives you plenty of room to insert the pad). 
Then insert the scotch bright pad all the way into one side of the clamp. Using the clamp press down hard (with your fingers), trapping the one side of the pad while tightly wrapping it around the body. Rub each corner to help the body crease into the pad. 
Then release the clamp a little bit and then push the other side in between the clamp and body. Once the pad is fully inserted and tight, screw down the clamp screws to secure everything. 
I will try and upload a video of the process in the future.

remixed_from.author: gswatts
remixed_from.title: Airlift pump - air powered water pump

description.text: The Dual Airlift Pump allows you to water two separate things from one airlift pump, with a part just as small as my single airlift pump. It requires twice as much airflow of course, no free lunch. The design is the same otherwise. A pair of downward-pointing tubes prevent air from forcing itself out of the airlift pump the wrong direction. They can be straight or coiled as long as they point down. Sources at http://burningsmell.org/3d/airlift/

I realized the "U" in my first airlift pump was superfluous -- air that forced its way to the bottom would just rise and escape out the other side of the U. It works just fine as a straight pipe, catching and holding momentary excesses of air. Cutting the U in half makes two reservoirs, and nothing's needed to hold the other side of the U any more. I used that spot as another airlift chamber. I also put the air channels into the edge of the tube instead of the middle, on the theory that would cause more turbulence. The dual pump definitely works. A big fish bubbler, a 2 liter pop bottle, 2 cans, some straws, and a lot of aquarium tubing were lashed up to show that the amount of water pumped is pretty close to the same on both sides. You need twice as much airflow to run a pair of pumps, of course. If one side stalls and the other keeps going, all else being equal, it probably needs more air.

I thought it would be fun to watch youtube or whatever while taking a shower. The phone for the majority stays totally dry thanks to the strategic placement of the phone. I have actually revised this model from the original which was never posted by making the main holder stronger, the cross supports snap in better and added a sound redirection support since it can be kind of hard to hear. This works with the Samsung S5/S6, but could work with the older versions and other phones like the iPhone series as well.
I grant permission to modify the model to fit your phone/shower door. Use netfabb to get dimensions.
I also plan to make a revision to the main holders to allow adjustment for different size shower doors.
I take no responsibility if your phone gets damaged from using this setup. If your bathroom fan doesn't evacuate enough air and it stays too humid and that humidity gets in your phone it can damage it and possibly destroy it as well as void the warranty. That being said, those who wish to risk it for some enjoyment have fun :).

author: matz13

title: bridge test - run this gcode to find out your bridging speeds. it means your plastic will float above surface!

description.text:
This g code  is code from a program i am releasing soon called 3d_simple. This code is a step forward as it visually tells you what you speeds and feeds should be on your printer. 
Bridging is the ability to cross over an open area and have the filament stretch and not melt or bend down. This program takes the guess work out!
Just remember to set the temp "M104" in the gcode file to whatever temp you print at.

open gcode up and modify the line/lines that say M104 Sxxx, change 'xxx' to the working temp of your machine in Celsius. I'm going to be brave and tell you that a few degrees above what is needed for plastic flow is ok. the way this test works is it bridges at several feed and extruder rates, you look for the 1st bridge up from the bottom where there is no sagging. (the 3d simple test is more complex, but this will get you in the ballpark) count lines bridged up until the perfect bridge. use these values based on that info. also keep in mind it is only set for the temp you set code too! count lines from bottom up, so first bridge up is 1, second bridge from bottom is 2,
count of perfect bridge= extrude rate
20EXTRUDE = .053
19EXTRUDE = .054
18EXTRUDE = .052
17EXTRUDE = .051
16EXTRUDE = .054
15EXTRUDE = .055
14EXTRUDE = .0545
13EXTRUDE = .068
12EXTRUDE = .069
11EXTRUDE = .07
10EXTRUDE = .072
9EXTRUDE = .073
8EXTRUDE = .0735
7EXTRUDE = .075
6EXTRUDE = .0765
5EXTRUDE = .0785
4EXTRUDE = .080
3EXTRUDE = .084
2EXTRUDE = .086
1EXTRUDE = .091 so look for first perfect bridge. then take your feed rate multiply it by the above number to get your feedrate with a bridge! don't slow extruder too much though, although plastic will go thin, it may also break apart.

This model was created for the MakerEd Challenge I created this model with the goal of giving students a clearer understanding of the bonds between elements. It's a simple yet effective design using spheres and sticks to illustrate the relationship between elements in a molecule. The element bodies and bonds can be color coded to distinguish the different elements and type of bond. In my experience having physical objects to look at and feel greatly improved my understanding of this matter. I hope that in the future, teachers can utilize the advancement of 3D printing to bring ideas similar to my own to the classroom. Molecules in photo
left to right: Carbon Dioxide, Hydrogen, Water, Methane, Dichloromethane, Carbon Tetrachloride

Printer:

Flash Forge Creator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Highest possible

Infill:

10-100%

Notes: The bonds and valence shell electrons will not fit the holes on the element bodies unless you are on the highest resolution possible. You may have to scale the bonds down a little or sand the ends down. If printed at a high resolution the bonds should fit nicely.

Element Bodies I created two different sized spheres. I punched holes on 6 sides for the bigger element body and 1 hole on the smaller element body. Bonds For the double bond I took a circle and revolved it 180 degrees.
For the single bond I formed a cylinder and extended it. Valence Shell Electrons For the Valence Electrons I took a basic shape and extruded it up to match the nub I created on the end. I then punched two holes to indicate it is a pair of electrons. To make it fit the holes in the element bodies, I rounded off the edges.

Objectives The goal of this project is to teach the structure of molecules and the exchange of valence electrons involved in the creation of the molecules. Audiences This project is tailored toward college prep chemistry courses taken by high school students, summer school chemistry classes, and home schooled students. Preparation In preparation for the use of this kit, students should be expected to know the charges of the valence electrons on an element and the octet rule*. *The octet rule is a chemical rule of thumb that reflects observation that atoms of main-group elements tend to combine in such a way that each atom has eight electrons in its valence shell, giving it the same electronic configuration as a noble gas. The rule is especially applicable to carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and the halogens, but also to metals such as sodium or magnesium. Cited: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octet_rule Steps Taking college prep chemistry in high school led me to think of an easier way to understand the relationships between the elements in creating a molecule. In turn I realized that visualizing the molecules in three dimensions greatly improved my understanding. Once I saw this contest back in January, I decided I could test my idea and share it for others to benefit from. The items may be reproduced multiple times to fit specific needs, especially if one breaks and there is an unporportionate ratio of items to students.
Labeling the element bodies is up to the teacher, and they can be color coded. The straight sticks are single bonds, the curved ones are double bonds, and they can be used together two double and one single for a triple bond. To print in batches I've provided 3D pdf files or programs can convert the "stl" files to the correct format for further editing. Results By the end of the project, students should be expected to build any molecules instructed by the teacher. Also they should be able to explain the exchange of electrons when creating a molecule and the reasons for it's stability as a molecule according to the octet rule*. *see "Preparation" section

My cousin for lending me his 3D printer for this project.
My brother for helping me put the molecules together.
My sister for taking the photos.

remixed_from.title: Oh nooo, another customizable thumb wheel / knob / screw / whatever :D

title: Minimalist but versatile Ultimaker spool holder

description.text:
Not very complex but does the job well. I needed it for some more projects (namely heterogeneous spools, or my spider spool http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:234040 for raw coils) The STL is for a 8 mm threaded rod, and it embeds an optional nut in the background. Still, you can customize it for other diameters, you could tailor it for a chopstick, as it would be a good candidate in place of adding a PVC tube as I did. No need to publish tons of derivatives ;) The customizer on my thumb wheels is useful to set different diameters for the end side (a 75mm one is included)
The openscad source code may prove useful to those who want a robust and parametric hook (constants can be changed also for the feeder hook).

The default diameter is tight so that the rod is held in place without the need for a nut nor counter-nut. I added a specific support to remove because I had some trouble with my fan setup and the (regular) overhang was ugly on one side, you can disable it in the customizer if you really do not want to print it.  
A rim helps it stick on the bed. Used 0.8mm walls and 20% infill.  
Update: added the main star and counter-nut for large rolls.

Bringing to you my next version of the GR8 PI Case Version 2.
I had a bunch of feedback and a request to " take the air out"  of the last design.  So I have created a shorter more symmetrical version.  This version is about 1.5" shorter than the original version.  This version can only house a 10mm thick 80mm x 80mm fan.  I have found most of these to be 5v x .3a so it is a little less stress on the Pi power as well.   And as always, you don't have to run a fan in this but that was what started it for me so I decided to just build off that.
This case is completely snap together when I printed it but I did leave some spots for hardware if you would like to mount it all together.  
Enjoy!  Feel free to add some feedback and I would love to see some pics of your makes!

This is my 3d puzzle box it can be customized to how ever you want to change the end part of the puzzle witch is the bottom I personalized and used my initials.
The basics are you drop the ball thru the top hole use the sliders to move the ball into the holes and make your way down once at the bottom just move the box side to side and make around the maze and out the end.
I have included the repaired version that i have used with netfabb, also the sketchup files and box ready mod is the one you can change your self
What you learn from this is how to be creative how to think out side of the box pun intended , its a fun project to make and to play with.
I don't have a 3d printer so the size on the  print bed is unknown but i have included the file of every thing arranged on the platform so you can just resize it or let your slicer do that. 
Every thing is numbered so the slide plates have numbers on the bottom of them so there set to print upside down just refer to the pics

Just quick tips Started with a basic box used the offset tool to make the inner wall and then used the push pull tool to make the perfect box. created the sliders from one square push pulled that and just copied them many times made them into components so they don't stick to the main box. placed them where i wanted and used them to mark the spot where i pushed pulled them.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Not sure how nobody has thought to make a motorcycle frame slider, but heres the one off my 1999 honda cbr 600 f4. this takes an aluminum insert so that it holds it securely. I just got the bike one one of the sliders had some road rash, so i already had all the parts necessary to do this. modify and use for your bike. recommend high infill for obvious reasons. im doing 60% honeycomb with PETG material. it is actually heavier by a marginal amount at 60%, so that makes me feel good about it. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jl2ELOfcnRE

author: rachbooks37

description.text:
This was designed to replace a broken cigarette lighter/power port housing in a 2005 Mini Cooper.  It probably fits other models too.
Installation is a bit tricky.  First, remove the cigarette lighter, unplug the wires,  and discard the broken housing.  Pull the wires through the bottom of the new housing and out the top.  Insert the new housing into the dash (without the cigarette lighter inserted into the housing), plug the wires into the cigarette lighter, and then push the lighter into the housing.  The housing is a tight fit, so if your printing material tends to shrink when cooling you may need to upscale the model by about 1% or so.
This replacement housing should only be used if you are using the cigarette lighter as a power port.  ABS and PLA (and potentially other materials) will not withstand the heat of a cigarette lighter.

description.text: These prints were designed to be a fun and simple tool for learning braille.  I worked to make the braille sizing as accurate as possible.

Project: Learning Braille Alphabet Objectives: Fun and simple blocks created to help students learn braille letters. Audiences: These blocks were built primarily for younger children but can be for any age. Preparation: All blocks will need to be printed. Multiple sets may need printed to form words. Steps! After the blocks are printed, the student will be able to practice reading Braille letters. Once the student is familiar with Braille, the student will be able to practice forming words by putting the letter blocks in order. Results: The students will learn the Braille alphabet.

This gnome is part of the growing collection of objects we've 3D scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner. Just two lasers, a turntable, and a camera generated this watertight, 3D-printable model in about 12 minutes.  
The original object was designed in ZBrush by MakerBot designers, and then printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 and painted. We then scanned that object with the MakerBot Digitizer and are sharing it so you can continue the creativity!  To compare the original version with this 3D scanned version, click "MakerBot Gnome" under "Derived From".  
With this STL file, you can modify, improve, or remix the gnome in any 3D modeling program just as you would any other 3D model designed on-screen.   
Resize him and turn him into smaller pieces for a game or diorama 3D scan a model car, scale it up a bit, and put your gnome in the driver's seat 3D print him on a MakerBot Replicator and paint him  
You know the deal. Explore, and have fun!

comments.text: Can someone explain the advantage of the two laser approach.
comments.author: notstarman

comments.text: The scan process works by taking advantage of the difference in angles between the camera and the laser. They are (it's assumed) both pointing at the same place so the displacement of the line will reveal the contours of the object. However what if there's a large protrusion, like a nose, that obscures the line as it turns? The result is a "shadow" of area that isn't filled in on the point cloud behind the nose. The solution is another laser on the other side to catch the geometry on that side of the protrusion as it comes around. And since the lasers are offset left and right it's easy for the software to figure out which line is which by splitting the analyzed area down the middle.

description.text:
The controller can be found here,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1384166 Piece C11 is UPDATED and ready for download as of 3/27/2016.
Just a slight change in zip-tie hole dimension for mounting the BEC next to the receiver. This is on going development of a mind influenced RC heliplane. Please join me as we have a platform for the development of a new type of racing.
Being able to transition between heli and plane will greatly aid in performing tight turns. While flying as a plane will allow to use higher speeds, and larger courses. These current V(ersion)3 designed pieces allow for a person to quickly swap out broken pieces if needed, since it's made of individual printed parts. Just print out extra pieces and bring them with you in case needed. The magnetic couplers are included in design for saving the gearing with in the servos. I have a site that I'm uploading build videos with a parts list called dragonflyRC.com. There you find more explanation on the project.
I've been perfecting these pieces for over a year now and prototyping just never ends so, I'm releasing these V3 pieces. All pieces have been updated many times and probably will NOT fit with any older released pieces. All V3 pieces Do have a V3 on the pieces when printing it out.
The transmitter will be it's own project to download.
Instructions at dragonflyRC.com.
The controller can be found here,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1384166 https://youtu.be/qtyn79TtITg
